tn.text: This word is used in English to introduce a new part of the story and background information about Sarai. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"slave-girl." This type of slave would serve the woman of the household.
"from giving birth to children"

tn.ref: I will have children by her
tn.text: "I will build my family through her"

tn.ref: Abram listened to the voice of Sarai
tn.text: "Abram did what Sarai said"

tn.ref: she looked with contempt on her mistress
tn.text: "she despised her mistress" or "she thought that she was more valuable than her mistress"
Here this refers to Sarai. A mistress has authority over her slave. AT: "her owner" or "Sarai"
"This injustice against me"
"is your responsibility" or "is your fault"

tn.ref: I gave my servant woman into your embrace
tn.text: Sarai used the word "embrace" here to refer to him sleeping with her. AT: "I gave you my servant so that you would sleep with her" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

tn.ref: I was despised in her eyes
tn.text: This can be active. AT: "she hated me" or "she began to hate me" or "she thought she was better than me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Let Yahweh judge between me and you
tn.text: "I want Yahweh to say whether this is my fault or your fault" or "I want Yahweh to decide which one of us is right." The phrase "to judge between" means to decide which person is right in a dispute between them.
"Listen to me" or "Pay attention"
"under your authority"
"Sarai treated Hagar very badly"
"and Hagar fled from Sarai"

Possible meanings are 1) Yahweh made himself look like an angel or 2) this was one of Yahweh's angels or 3) this was a special messenger from God (some scholars think it was Jesus). Since the phrase is not well understood, it is best to simply translate it as "the angel of Yahweh" using the normal word that you use for "angel."
The wilderness area she went to was a desert. AT: "desert"
This was the name of a place south of Canaan and east of Egypt.
Here this refers to Sarai. A mistress has authority over her slave. AT: "my owner." See how "her mistress" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:01|16:4]].

tn.ref: The angel of Yahweh said to her
tn.text: "The angel of Yahweh said to Hagar"
See the note about this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:07|16:7]].
Sarai. See how "her mistress" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:01|16:4]].

tn.ref: the angel of Yahweh said to her, "I
tn.text: When he said "I," he was referring to Yahweh. When translating what is in the quote, do it as the angel of Yahweh did and use the word "I" when referring to Yahweh.

tn.ref: I will greatly multiply your descendants
tn.text: "I will give you very many descendants"
"so many that no one will be able to count them"
See the note about this phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:16:07|16:7]].
"Look" or "Listen" or "Pay attention"
"give birth to a son"
"you will name him." The word "you" refers to Hagar.
Translators may add a footnote that says "The name 'Ishmael' means 'God has heard.'"
She has been afflicted by distress and suffering.

tn.ref: He will be a wild donkey of a man
tn.text: This was not an insult. It may mean that Ishmael would be independent and strong like a wild donkey. AT: "He will be like a wild donkey among men" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: He will be hostile against every man
tn.text: "He will be every man's enemy"

tn.ref: every man will be hostile to him
tn.text: "everyone will be his enemy"
This can also mean "he will live in hostility with."
"relatives" or "kin"
"Yahweh, because he spoke to her"

tn.ref: Do I really continue to see, ... me?
tn.text: Hagar used this rhetorical question to express her amazement that she was still alive even after she met God. People expected that if they met God, they would die. AT: "I am surprised that I am still alive, ... me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Therefore the well was called Beerlahairoi
tn.text: Translators may add a footnote that says "Beerlahairoi means 'the well of the living one who sees me.'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: behold, it is between Kadesh and Bered
tn.text: The word "behold" here draws attention to the fact that the well was in a place that the author and his readers knew. AT: "in fact, it is between Kadesh and Bered" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Hagar's return to Sarai and Abram is implict. You can make this more explicit. AT: "So Hagar went back and gave birth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: named his son, whom Hagar bore
tn.text: "named his son by Hagar" or "named his and Hagar's son"

This introduces background information about Abram's age when these things happened. Your language may have a special way to mark background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This means "gave birth to Abram's son, Ishmael." The focus is on Abram having a son.
